hook.text: Eating disorders aren't about food. They're about control, pain, and survival.

buildup.text: These are serious psychiatric illnesses with the highest mortality rate of any mental disorder.

discovery.text: About 9 percent of the global population will have an eating disorder in their lifetime.

twist.text: They affect all genders, ages, races, and body sizes â€” not just thin white girls.

climax.text: Early intervention dramatically improves outcomes but most cases go undiagnosed for years.

punchline.text: The deadliest mental illness is the one people least understand.

quiz.question: Which mental illness has the highest mortality rate?

hook.text: There are more eating disorders than most people realize â€” and they look very different.

buildup.text: The DSM-5 recognizes anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, and binge eating disorder.

discovery.text: ARFID, pica, rumination disorder, and other specified disorders round out the category.

twist.text: OSFED â€” other specified feeding disorder â€” is actually the most common diagnosis.

climax.text: Many people move between diagnoses over time as their disorder evolves.

punchline.text: Eating disorders don't fit neat boxes. Neither do the people who have them.

quiz.question: What is the most common eating disorder diagnosis?
options: OSFED â€” other specified feeding disorder

hook.text: The first sign of an eating disorder is rarely about weight. It's about withdrawal.

buildup.text: Skipping meals, rigid food rules, and avoiding eating with others are early red flags.

discovery.text: Excessive exercise, body checking, and growing secrecy around food follow.

twist.text: Many people with eating disorders maintain a normal weight, making detection harder.

climax.text: Physical signs include hair loss, fatigue, dizziness, and disrupted menstrual cycles.

punchline.text: You can't see an eating disorder by looking at someone's body.

quiz.question: Why are eating disorders often missed in diagnosis?
options: Many people maintain a normal weight despite having one

hook.text: Starvation changes the brain so profoundly that it perpetuates its own continuation.

buildup.text: Malnutrition alters serotonin, dopamine, and cortisol â€” reshaping mood and cognition.

discovery.text: The hypothalamus, which regulates hunger, becomes dysregulated in eating disorders.

twist.text: Restriction can produce a euphoric high as the body releases endorphins in response to starvation.

climax.text: This biological hijacking makes recovery feel worse before it feels better.

punchline.text: The disease rewires the brain to resist its own cure.

quiz.question: Why can food restriction produce a temporary high?
options: The body releases endorphins in response to starvation
Food restriction has no brain effect

hook.text: One in three people with eating disorders is male. Most will never be diagnosed.

buildup.text: Male eating disorders often focus on muscularity rather than thinness.

discovery.text: Muscle dysmorphia â€” the drive for extreme muscularity â€” is a growing male-specific concern.

twist.text: Stigma and the myth that eating disorders are a women's problem prevent men from seeking help.

climax.text: Men with eating disorders have higher mortality rates partly due to delayed diagnosis.

punchline.text: The disorder doesn't discriminate. The diagnosis does.

quiz.question: What proportion of eating disorder cases are male?

hook.text: Anorexia has the highest death rate of any psychiatric illness â€” up to 10 percent.

buildup.text: It involves severe food restriction, intense fear of weight gain, and distorted body image.

discovery.text: The brain of someone with anorexia literally sees a larger body than what exists.

twist.text: Atypical anorexia involves the same behaviors and dangers but at a normal or higher weight.

climax.text: Starvation damages the heart, bones, brain, and every organ system in the body.

punchline.text: The mirror lies. The damage is real.

quiz.question: What makes anorexia the most lethal psychiatric illness?
options: It has up to a 10 percent mortality rate

hook.text: In 1944, healthy men volunteered to starve â€” and developed eating disorder symptoms.

buildup.text: Ancel Keys recruited 36 conscientious objectors to study the effects of semi-starvation.

discovery.text: The men became obsessed with food, anxious, depressed, and socially withdrawn.

twist.text: During refeeding, many binged uncontrollably â€” showing restriction itself triggers bingeing.

climax.text: The study proved that many anorexia symptoms are caused by starvation, not personality.

punchline.text: Starve anyone long enough and the mind unravels the same way.

quiz.question: What did the Minnesota Starvation Experiment demonstrate?
options: Starvation itself causes many eating disorder symptoms
Only people with weak wills develop eating disorders

hook.text: The heart muscle weakens when it's broken down for fuel during starvation.

buildup.text: Anorexia causes bradycardia, low blood pressure, and cardiac arrhythmias.

discovery.text: Bone density drops dangerously â€” many young patients develop osteoporosis normally seen in the elderly.

twist.text: The brain physically shrinks during starvation, affecting cognition and decision-making.

climax.text: Most medical complications are reversible with adequate nutrition â€” but not all.

punchline.text: The body keeps the score of every missed meal.

quiz.question: What happens to the brain during starvation from anorexia?

hook.text: When life feels chaotic, controlling food becomes the one thing that feels manageable.

buildup.text: Many people with anorexia describe restriction as giving them a sense of mastery and safety.

discovery.text: Perfectionism and anxiety often precede anorexia â€” the disorder channels existing traits.

twist.text: The illusion of control becomes its own prison â€” the disorder demands more and more.

climax.text: Recovery means learning to tolerate uncertainty without retreating to restriction.

punchline.text: Control was the promise. Loss of freedom was the price.

quiz.question: What psychological need does anorexia often fulfill?
options: A sense of control and mastery when life feels chaotic

hook.text: Eating again after starvation can be more dangerous than the starvation itself.

buildup.text: Refeeding syndrome occurs when nutrition is reintroduced too quickly after prolonged restriction.

discovery.text: Rapid shifts in electrolytes â€” especially phosphate â€” can cause heart failure and death.

twist.text: This is why anorexia recovery requires careful medical supervision, not just eating more.

climax.text: Slow, monitored refeeding saves lives â€” the body needs time to readjust to nourishment.

punchline.text: Even the cure must be handled with extreme care.

quiz.question: What causes refeeding syndrome?
options: Nutrition reintroduced too quickly causes dangerous electrolyte shifts

hook.text: Bulimia hides in plain sight â€” most people with it maintain a normal weight.

buildup.text: It involves cycles of binge eating followed by purging through vomiting or other methods.

discovery.text: The binge provides temporary relief from emotional pain; purging restores a sense of control.

twist.text: Purging doesn't actually prevent calorie absorption â€” the body absorbs most before vomiting.

climax.text: Stomach acid erodes tooth enamel, damages the esophagus, and disrupts heart rhythms.

punchline.text: The cycle promises relief but delivers destruction.

quiz.question: Does purging effectively prevent calorie absorption?
options: No â€” most calories are absorbed before purging occurs
Yes â€” it eliminates all calories

hook.text: Binge eating disorder is the most common eating disorder â€” and the least talked about.

buildup.text: It involves eating large amounts rapidly while feeling unable to stop, without purging.

discovery.text: The shame and distress after a binge often trigger another one â€” creating a vicious cycle.

twist.text: It wasn't recognized as a formal diagnosis until 2013 in the DSM-5.

climax.text: BED affects about 3 percent of Americans â€” more than anorexia and bulimia combined.

punchline.text: The most common eating disorder hid in shame for decades.

quiz.question: When was binge eating disorder first recognized as a formal diagnosis?

hook.text: Dieting is the most consistent predictor of future binge eating. That's not a coincidence.

buildup.text: Restriction triggers biological hunger signals that eventually overwhelm willpower.

discovery.text: The brain interprets restriction as famine and drives compensatory overeating to survive.

twist.text: The binge isn't a failure of self-control â€” it's the body's survival mechanism working perfectly.

climax.text: Breaking the cycle requires consistent, adequate eating â€” not more restriction.

punchline.text: The diet starts the cycle. Eating enough ends it.

quiz.question: What is the most consistent predictor of binge eating?

hook.text: Vomiting isn't the only purge method â€” and all of them can be deadly.

buildup.text: Laxatives, diuretics, excessive exercise, and fasting are all forms of purging behavior.

discovery.text: Laxative abuse causes severe dehydration and electrolyte imbalances that affect the heart.

twist.text: Exercise purging is often praised by others, making it the hardest form to recognize.

climax.text: Any compensatory behavior driven by guilt after eating is a form of purging.

punchline.text: When exercise is punishment, it's no longer healthy.

quiz.question: Why is exercise purging difficult to identify?
options: Society praises excessive exercise, disguising the behavior

topics.title: ARFID: When Picky Eating Is Serious

hook.text: A child eats only five foods and gags at anything new. It's not just picky eating.

buildup.text: ARFID â€” avoidant restrictive food intake disorder â€” involves extreme food avoidance.

discovery.text: It's driven by sensory sensitivity, fear of choking, or lack of interest in food, not body image.

twist.text: ARFID can cause severe nutritional deficiencies and growth problems in children.

climax.text: It was only added to the DSM in 2013 and is still widely misunderstood.

punchline.text: Not every eating disorder is about wanting to be thin.

quiz.question: How does ARFID differ from anorexia?
options: ARFID is not driven by body image concerns

hook.text: If your identical twin has anorexia, your risk is 50 to 80 percent. Genes matter.

buildup.text: Genome-wide studies have identified multiple genes linked to eating disorder risk.

discovery.text: These genes overlap with those for anxiety, depression, OCD, and metabolism.

twist.text: Anorexia has genetic links to both psychiatric traits and metabolic factors like low BMI.

climax.text: Genetics loads the vulnerability, but environment and culture pull the trigger.

punchline.text: You inherit the risk. You don't inherit the destiny.

quiz.question: What is the heritability risk if an identical twin has anorexia?

hook.text: Up to 50 percent of people with eating disorders report a history of trauma.

buildup.text: Sexual abuse, physical abuse, and emotional neglect are strongly linked to eating disorders.

discovery.text: Controlling food becomes a way to manage overwhelming emotions from unprocessed trauma.

twist.text: The eating disorder numbs pain â€” restriction starves feelings, bingeing buries them.

climax.text: Trauma-informed treatment addresses the root wound, not just the eating behaviors.

punchline.text: The eating disorder is the symptom. The trauma is the cause.

quiz.question: What percentage of people with eating disorders report trauma history?

topics.title: Diet Culture as a Risk Factor

hook.text: The $72 billion diet industry profits from the same behaviors eating disorders punish.

buildup.text: Diet culture glorifies restriction, labels foods as good or bad, and moralizes body size.

discovery.text: Research shows dieting in adolescence increases eating disorder risk fivefold.

twist.text: Many eating disorders begin as diets that were praised by family, friends, and doctors.

climax.text: The line between disordered eating and a normal diet is thinner than we admit.

punchline.text: When a culture celebrates restriction, disorders hide in plain sight.

quiz.question: How much does adolescent dieting increase eating disorder risk?

hook.text: In sports that reward leanness, eating disorders are three times more common.

buildup.text: Gymnastics, wrestling, distance running, and dance have the highest rates.

discovery.text: The female athlete triad â€” low energy, menstrual loss, and weak bones â€” is a medical crisis.

twist.text: Coaches sometimes encourage restriction, confusing disordered eating with discipline.

climax.text: Relative Energy Deficiency in Sport (RED-S) now describes the broader syndrome in all athletes.

punchline.text: Performance built on starvation always collapses.

quiz.question: Which sports have the highest eating disorder rates?
options: Those that reward leanness like gymnastics and distance running
Team sports like football and basketball

hook.text: Thirty minutes on Instagram increases body dissatisfaction measurably in studies.

buildup.text: Filtered photos, edited bodies, and comparison culture flood social media feeds.

discovery.text: Meta's own leaked research showed Instagram worsened body image in teenage girls.

twist.text: Pro-eating-disorder communities thrive online, sharing tips disguised as motivation.

climax.text: Yet social media also hosts recovery communities that provide genuine support.

punchline.text: The same screen can poison or heal. The feed matters.

quiz.question: What did Meta's internal research reveal about Instagram?
options: It worsened body image in teenage girls
It had no effect on body image

hook.text: The most effective treatment for teen anorexia puts parents in charge of refeeding.

buildup.text: FBT, or the Maudsley approach, empowers parents as the primary agents of recovery.

discovery.text: Parents take over meal planning and supervision until the teen can eat independently.

twist.text: This reversed decades of blaming parents for causing eating disorders.

climax.text: FBT has the strongest evidence base for adolescent anorexia of any treatment.

punchline.text: Parents went from being blamed to being the cure.

quiz.question: What does family-based treatment involve?
options: Parents take charge of the teen's refeeding and meal supervision
Removing the teen from the family
Only individual therapy for the teen

hook.text: The leading treatment for bulimia and binge eating targets the thoughts, not just the food.

buildup.text: CBT-E (enhanced) addresses the distorted beliefs about weight, shape, and self-worth.

discovery.text: It normalizes eating patterns and challenges the rigid food rules driving the disorder.

twist.text: About 50 percent of people with bulimia fully recover with CBT-E alone.

climax.text: CBT-E works across all eating disorder diagnoses â€” not just bulimia.

punchline.text: Fix the thinking and the eating follows.

quiz.question: What is CBT-E designed to treat?
options: Distorted beliefs about weight, shape, and self-worth in eating disorders

hook.text: Not all eating disorders need a hospital â€” but some absolutely do.

buildup.text: Treatment ranges from outpatient therapy to residential programs to full hospitalization.

discovery.text: Higher levels provide supervised meals, medical monitoring, and 24-hour therapeutic support.

twist.text: Insurance often denies higher care levels, discharging patients before they're medically stable.

climax.text: Step-down care â€” gradually reducing support â€” has the best long-term outcomes.

punchline.text: The right level of care saves lives. Denial of care costs them.

quiz.question: What does higher-level eating disorder care provide?
options: Supervised meals, medical monitoring, and 24-hour support

hook.text: There is only one FDA-approved medication for any eating disorder â€” just one.

buildup.text: Fluoxetine (Prozac) is approved for bulimia nervosa to reduce binge-purge cycles.

discovery.text: Lisdexamfetamine is approved for binge eating disorder to reduce binge frequency.

twist.text: No medication has proven effective for anorexia nervosa â€” therapy remains the primary treatment.

climax.text: Medications treat co-occurring conditions like depression and anxiety alongside the eating disorder.

punchline.text: Pills help, but recovery is built in the kitchen and the therapy room.

quiz.question: Is there an FDA-approved medication for anorexia nervosa?
options: No â€” no medication has proven effective for anorexia

hook.text: About 60 percent of people treated for eating disorders achieve full recovery.

buildup.text: Recovery means not just stopping behaviors but building a healthy relationship with food and body.

discovery.text: The brain needs consistent nutrition to heal â€” physical recovery must come first.

twist.text: Recovery is rarely linear â€” setbacks are normal and don't erase progress.

climax.text: People who maintain recovery for five years rarely relapse â€” the brain has truly healed.

punchline.text: Recovery isn't going back to who you were. It's becoming who you can be.

quiz.question: What percentage of treated people achieve full eating disorder recovery?

hook.text: Marilyn Monroe was a size 12. Today's models are thinner than 95 percent of the population.

buildup.text: Beauty ideals have shifted dramatically across cultures and centuries.

discovery.text: The thin ideal emerged in Western culture in the 1960s with Twiggy and the fashion industry.

twist.text: Cultures without Western media exposure have significantly lower eating disorder rates.

climax.text: When Fiji got television in 1995, eating disorders appeared within three years.

punchline.text: Change the images a culture sees and you change the bodies it rejects.

quiz.question: What happened after television was introduced in Fiji in 1995?
options: Eating disorders appeared within three years

hook.text: Doctors spend less time with larger patients and order fewer tests. Bias kills.

buildup.text: Weight stigma is discrimination based on body size â€” and it's the last acceptable prejudice.

discovery.text: Studies show weight stigma increases cortisol, inflammation, and avoidance of healthcare.

twist.text: The stress of stigma causes more health damage than the weight itself in many cases.

climax.text: Weight-neutral healthcare improves outcomes by focusing on behaviors, not the scale.

punchline.text: Shaming people thinner has never worked. Science confirms it.

quiz.question: What does research show about weight stigma and health?
options: Stigma stress causes significant health damage independent of weight

hook.text: Body positivity started as a radical political movement â€” not an Instagram hashtag.

buildup.text: It originated in fat activism of the 1960s fighting for civil rights of larger-bodied people.

discovery.text: Social media democratized the movement, showing diverse bodies as worthy and beautiful.

twist.text: Critics argue it's been commercialized and still excludes disabled and very large bodies.

climax.text: Body neutrality â€” accepting your body without loving or hating it â€” emerged as an alternative.

punchline.text: You don't have to love your body. You just have to live in it.

quiz.question: Where did the body positivity movement originate?
options: Fat activism of the 1960s fighting for civil rights

hook.text: What if the best diet was learning to trust the body you've been fighting against?

buildup.text: Intuitive eating, created by Evelyn Tribole and Elyse Resch in 1995, rejects diet culture.

discovery.text: Its ten principles include honoring hunger, rejecting the diet mentality, and feeling fullness.

twist.text: Research shows intuitive eaters have better metabolic health and lower eating disorder rates.

climax.text: It's increasingly used in eating disorder recovery to rebuild trust with food.

punchline.text: Your body knew how to eat before diet culture told it to stop.

quiz.question: What is the foundation of intuitive eating?
options: Trusting internal hunger and fullness cues instead of diet rules

hook.text: Preventing eating disorders costs a fraction of treating them â€” yet prevention is underfunded.

buildup.text: Media literacy programs help young people critically evaluate unrealistic body images.

discovery.text: The Body Project â€” a dissonance-based program â€” reduces eating disorder risk by 60 percent.

twist.text: Teaching about eating disorders in schools without careful design can accidentally normalize them.

climax.text: The most protective factors are self-esteem, media literacy, and rejecting the thin ideal.

punchline.text: An ounce of prevention is worth a lifetime of recovery.

quiz.question: How much does the Body Project reduce eating disorder risk?
